Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I stood in the hallway, the faint scent of disinfectant clinging to my uniform. My daughter’s voice echoed from the living room, excitement bubbling as she called everyone to gather—my grandson had just won his first art competition, and the family was waiting for me to join the celebration. I glanced down at my hands, still gloved from scrubbing the bathroom. The checklist from my supervisor replayed in my mind: gloves on for chemicals, never touch personal items, always wash up before leaving the cleaning zone. But my family’s laughter and the proud look on my grandson’s face tugged at me. They expected me to be present, to share in this special moment, to be the doting grandfather. Yet, the protocols demanded I finish my tasks properly, keep everyone safe, and not bring any germs into the family space. My heart ached as I stood at the threshold, torn between the warmth of my family and the cold, necessary rules of my job.
